title: You can't feed AND be toxic
body:
Choose one jheez.

If you're gonna be toxic, at least be 20-0 so I can mute you and ride free lp.

If you're 0-20, at least TRY not to blame the Jungler and don't write gg after every death.

I'm beyond expecting people to actually be respectable human beings at this point so compromise with me.

replies.body:
You should never be toxic

FIFY

You're forgetting that players are "human". These "humans" tend to have "emotions". It just so happens that not everyone can control them in the middle of a tight game. Setting the standard at "never rage, never toxic, never feed" is going to lead you to nothing but disappointment. It's best to design a system with human nature in mind, as opposed to forcing people to change their very nature to fit this absurd system.

Low Priority queues, loss of seasonal rewards (that you worked hard for and _earned_ through skill), chat restrictions, permanent bans for some measly shit you said in chat, no hextech loot, etc. etc. etc. It's just one shackle after another. And it'll keep on coming, and coming, and coming. And as long as you have that attitude, you'll keep sucking it up and taking it in the ass, one punishment after another. 

It's time the system was redesigned not to punish toxicity, but to preemptively eliminate it. Give me fucking voice comms so that my teammates feel humanized, so that I can hear their voices and know that they are real people.  Give me sandbox mode so I we can all practice our flashes and not throw games over stupid shit. Fix matchmaking so that people with high win streaks don't purposefully get matched on the same team as people with loss streaks. There's lots of shit you can do to fix toxicity that isn't "more bans" or "more restrictions". Telling people to "never be toxic" is not one of them. If anything, it actually makes you seem like an elitist, condescending, pretentious, holier-than-thou fuckwit.

You don't reward people in the real world for not stealing, do you? Because its expected behavior. The same way being polite or at least silent is expected in LOL.

I agree. Toxicity is subjective. We could have a long discourse on the properties of objectivity, and then realise that the very notion of objectivity is the subject of subjective speculation on a fair number of philosophers. Am I observing a ball objectively, or is it merely my opinion that the round-shaped object I am observing is a ball (and therefore subjective)?

Your argument that toxicity is subjective is not bad in and of itself, but the broader argument it supports ("it's therefore difficult to tell what is and is not acceptable") is less agreeable to me.

There are a fair number of "obvious" societal guidelines which anyone, provided they are not autistic or otherwise mentally impaired, can intuit as to what is acceptable conduct. Very few people would believe that, when meeting with your prospective boss for the first time in a job interview, calling them an "ugly, fat bitch" would be a good idea. It seems fairly obvious that it's a poor move.

In that sense, people can intuit that informing one of your team mates in a team game that you opine their mother is "a fat whale [you] raped while making [their] father watch" is a poor choice of action. Although subjective, I predict many people will be able to intuit that this is generally undesirable behaviour, and I predict receiving punishment for the transgression should not surprise a great deal of people─except, of course, the one being punished, since they already made the incorrect judgement that their behaviour was in no way rude or objectionable. (In which case, we could field a discussion on the properties of sociopathy.)

What I do agree is hard to judge are the finer instances of 'toxic behaviour'. If your team mate is performing poorly and you inform them that they should think a moment longer before diving once more, this behaviour could be interpreted as "criticising a team mate" and "harassing them" for making mistakes, but it can also be argued as constructive behaviour designed to improve the likelihood of victory.

That's unfortunately behaviour heavily subject to context, circumstance and personal experience, and I daresay it'd be impossible to forge a set of rules so encompassing it can take into account these situations. A summative list of "naughty" words might be helpful, but consider that the word 'trap' is fairly innocuous... unless used to refer to a transgender woman, in which case it can be downright offensive.

Generally, though, the people who complain on the boards about the subjectivity of toxic behaviour exhibit behaviours which aren't so fine. 

Telling your teammate that he should "go kill himself" is much easier to argue as being undesired behaviour. There are very few situations in the world where telling someone to "go kill yourself" is considered appropriate behaviour.
